posts.title: Three student entrepreneurs in competition final
posts.title_plain: Three student entrepreneurs in competition final
posts.content:
Three out of five finalists in a competition to find the best young entrepreneurial talent are students from the University of Portsmouth. The prize for the winner is a fund worth up to £50,000 of business products and services.

The Young Startup Talent Competition is aimed at students aged 16-25 who have a business idea they want to develop. The initiative promotes innovation, entrepreneurship, leadership and talent development. The competition is broken into regions and in the Solent region the University has claim to three finalists.

Finalists – left to right – John Wheal, Casper Nielson, Harry Phelan, Calvin Macleod and Ming Wu

Ming Wu, currently studying the MRes Technology, is developing a suite of wearable technology with a fashionable twist under his company, UU-U Design. In the future he hopes to take wearable technology to the next level, monitoring biomedical information such as heart health and blood pressure.

While studying, Ming has been developing his plans from his base in Innovation Space, a University of Portsmouth owned and managed Enterprise Centre where he and his fellow finalist, John Wheal would bounce ideas off each other. He said: “Everyone in the centre was working on something so the atmosphere was one of motivation and inspiration.”

John Wheal graduated from the MEng Computer Engineering course this year. He has developed an online space that helps to simplify the management and organisation of groups, clubs and societies. He said: “The feedback during the process has been invaluable and has prepared me for pitching my business in now and in the future.”

Calvin Macleod, who graduated from the BSc Computing course this year, has launched Life Beacon, a mobile base application that provides tools for users and patients to manage their medical health by providing reminders, calendars, notes, prescriptions and a day-to-day diary. He said: “I’ve found the whole experience invaluable. In fact, it’s because of this process that I recently secured a job in business development!”

All three students are from the Faculty of Technology and have received support and advice from the University’s student enterprise team who hosted a workshop with Young Startup Talent in March.

To reach the final the candidates worked their way through different business workshops, as well as a speed-networking event, which involved local business professionals grilling and feeding back their worldly wisdom and expertise to the young entrepreneurs on their business ideas. In September the final five candidates pitched their refined business plans at the Ocean Village Innovation Centre Southampton, to a panel of judges in a ‘Dragon’s Den’ style event.

The results will be announced tomorrow and the winner will secure a prize fund worth up to £50k worth of business products and services. The prize fund is donated by sponsors and local businesses to help ensure the lucky winner will have all the assistance they need to kick-start their new business.
posts.excerpt: Three out of five finalists in a competition to find the best young entrepreneurial talent are students/graduates from the Faculty of Technology.

attachments.caption: Finalists - left to right - John Wheal, Casper Nielson, Harry Phelan, Calvin Macleod and Ming Wu

posts.title: Invoice fraud alert
posts.content:
The Income team has been alerted to a serious scam/fraud in which one of our students has been sent an invoice for tuition fees from the email address portsmouthuniversity@aol.co.uk.

The payee bank account on this invoice is not the University’s bank account.

The email is not from the University.

The University will only ever issue invoices to you from the email address income@port.ac.uk or, on occasion, a reprinted invoice issued by a member of the University’s income team.

If you should receive, or have received, invoices from the University from any other email address, please refer these as a matter of urgency to income@port.ac.uk or call the income team on 023 9284 5533.
posts.excerpt: The Income team has been alerted to a serious scam/fraud in which one of our students has been sent a fake invoice for tuition fees.

posts.title: Need help? Don’t suffer in silence
posts.title_plain: Need help? Don’t suffer in silence
posts.content:
The University support and wellbeing services are here to help you.

Whatever your worries, even if you’re just concerned about someone else, remember that you are not alone.

The University support and wellbeing teams offer a confidential service to help you enjoy university life to the full. Please contact them – even if all you want to do is talk.

Contact numbers are listed below and you can find information about these and all the other University services at www.myport.ac.uk.

  • Student Wellbeing Service: 023 9284 3466
  • Halls’ Student Support team:
    James Watson, Greetham Street, Margaret Rule, Trafalgar, Bateson and Harry Law Halls: 023 9284 3880
    Rees Hall and Burrell House: 023 9284 3884
    Langstone Student Village: 023 9284 4529
  • Student Housing: 023 9284 3214
  • Student Finance Centre: 023 9284 3014
  • Students’ Union Advice Service: 023 9284 3478
  • Additional Support and Disability Advice Centre (ASDAC): 023 9284 3462
  • Chaplaincy: 023 9284 3030
  • Sport and Recreation: 023 9284 5555
  • Campus security: 023 9284 333
posts.excerpt: Whatever your worries, even if you’re just concerned about someone else, remember that you are not alone. The University support and wellbeing teams offer a confidential service to help you enjoy university life to the full.

posts.title: Scholarship set to boost student’s career
posts.title_plain: Scholarship set to boost student’s career
posts.content:
A University of Portsmouth student has been awarded a prestigious Naval Engineering Science and Technology scholarship, one of only 12 in the UK.

Emma Barclay, 22, studying BSc Business Information Systems, was awarded the scholarship by the United Kingdom Naval Engineering Science and Technology Forum (UKNEST) for students interested in employment in the naval defence sector.    

Emma applied for the scholarship, worth £3000, after completing a 12 month industrial placement at QinetiQ, a defence company with a large base in Portsmouth.  She wrote a 500 word essay on ‘The role of autonomous technology in the future Royal Navy’ and submitted this with her CV and a reference from her Personal Tutor. She was then short-listed and invited to attend an interview at the Lloyds Register Foundation building in London with a panel of representatives, to whom she had to present on the same topic as her essay.

She believes she was selected based on her placement in the defence industry at QinetiQ and the work she was already doing for them in their Maritime section, plus her strong desire to play a role in the future of the Royal Navy’s technology.

She said: “I’m fascinated by cyber security and interested in project management and both are key to a career in within the defence industry, which is what I’ve set my heart on. Being awarded the scholarship is a confidence boost and is a great thing to have on my CV.”

Emma is in her final year of a four year sandwich degree and when she graduates next year she hopes to secure a job in the defence industry or with the Royal Navy. Meanwhile she has become a Placement and Employability Ambassador at the University, and regularly talks to other students about the value of placements.

“My placement year made it possible to apply for the scholarship but it’s given me so much more in the way of invaluable knowledge and skills making me more employable within my chosen field.”

Emma will attend an awards ceremony at Plymouth Naval Base on 2 November, which includes a tour of a warship and a dinner at HMS Drake. “I’m excited about the ceremony which will be a lovely evening and a fantastic opportunity to meet more people in the industry,” she said.

Her Personal Tutor, Dr Nick Savage who is Head of the School of Computing, said, he was extremely proud of Emma’s achievements. “Emma is a shining example of our proactive students.  During her placement year she impressed her line manager, her colleagues and me, and I continue to be impressed by her dedication and commitment. I expect great things from her in the future.”
posts.excerpt: A University of Portsmouth student has been awarded a prestigious Naval Engineering Science and Technology scholarship, one of only 12 in the UK.

posts.title: Funding support for EU students
posts.content:
The Government announced on 11 October that European Union students who want to study at English universities in the 2017–18 academic year will still have access to student funding support.

EU students applying for a place at an English university, or further education institution, in the 2017–18 academic year can seek the same funding and support as they are now and their eligibility will continue throughout their course, even if the UK exits the European Union during that period.

For further enquiries on the EU announcement contact the Student Finance Centre: student.finance@port.ac.uk.
posts.excerpt: The Government has announced that European Union students who want to study at English universities in the 2017–18 academic year will still have access to student funding support.

posts.title: Recognition for teaching in tv and film
posts.title_plain: Recognition for teaching in tv and film
posts.content:
The University of Portsmouth has just won a prestigious award for teaching cinematography and camera craft.

The ‘Bill Vinten Guild of Television Cameraman (GTC) University Award‘ celebrates excellence in the teaching of cinematography and camera craft to undergraduate students. It was developed to encourage high quality teaching across multiple genres and reward new talent emerging through that teaching. The trophy goes to the university with the highest scoring portfolio of films and the award is well-recognised within the film industry.

Ben Thomson (left) and Steve Whitford (right) receive the award from TVCET Chair, Stuart McKears

Lecturers on the BA (Hons) Film Production course submitted three student films from three different categories – drama, documentary and music video. The judges especially look for a breadth of skills across different genres and the quality across the Portsmouth submissions this year secured them first prize.

Principal Lecturer, Ben Thompson, Section Lead Film and Broadcasting, said that the quality of the submissions reflected the calibre of the teaching and the continued investment in industry-standard equipment.

“All of our staff come from the film or television industry and this is reflected in how they teach, with a strong focus on cinematography. The fact that our students can produce films of professional industry standard and demonstrate creativity and quality in camera craft impressed the judges. It’s also what makes our students highly employable in the industry.

“We recently invested heavily in professional ARRi ALEXA cameras, which are used on today’s top feature films. The superiority of these cameras is evident in the quality of the films and is another ingredient in the overall production values of our students’ work.”

Josh Davies, who is a 2016 graduate of the course, was also shortlisted for an individual award for his music video, EKKOES. The drama submission was by Danny Ellis for Paenitenia, the story of a son who returns home to reconcile his broken relationship with his father decades after being exiled, and the documentary was A Step Too Far by Jon Cook about a group of dedicated young gymnasts. All of the entries can be viewed here.

Ben Thompson attended the award ceremony with Course Leader, Steve Whitford, and Lecturer on the course, Dan Mulligan. Ben said they were thrilled to win and collect the main prize on the night.

“Being recognised by industry peers is a real testimony of how we teach our students, specifically within the camera department, and it was a very happy and proud moment!”

As winners of the trophy, the University of Portsmouth will host next year’s awards ceremony providing a great opportunity for students to meet industry professionals and staff and students from other institutions.
posts.excerpt: The University of Portsmouth has just won a prestigious award for teaching cinematography and camera craft.

posts.title: Speaking with confidence and giving presentations
posts.title_plain: Speaking with confidence and giving presentations
posts.content:
This workshop run by the Academic Skills Unit will help you to look and feel more confident when speaking in front of others.

It deals with the effects of nerves and will help you to project yourself well and engage your audience. It will also help polish existing skills. It will assist your performance in assessed presentations or practice, and contribute to your future graduate career and interview skills.

You can attend individually or as a group (please note that numbers are limited). If you cannot attend any of the timetabled workshops, you are invited to form a group of three or more for a bespoke workshop.

To book on a timetabled workshop:  http://bit.ly/ask-workshops
For enquiries, to book a one-to-one session or request a bespoke workshop: academicskills@port.ac.uk or phone 023 9284 3462
posts.excerpt: Look and feel more confident when speaking in front of others.

posts.title: Don’t forget to wear pink! Pink Wednesday: 12 October
posts.title_plain: Don’t forget to wear pink! Pink Wednesday: 12 October
posts.content:
Each year the Students’ Union hold a Pink Wednesday event for Breast Cancer Now, the UK’s largest breast cancer charity.

Breast Cancer Now aims that, by 2050, everyone who develops breast cancer will live.

Pink Wednesday this year will be on Wednesday 12 October. 

This event is run by RAG Portsmouth, the student fundraising group from the Students’ Union. Last year, Pink Wednesday raised over £2000 and this year RAG Portsmouth would like your help to raise even more.

The money raised for the charity will fund world-class research across the UK and Ireland to discover how to prevent breast cancer, how to detect it earlier and how to treat it effectively at every stage. They are also finding ways to stop secondary breast cancer – when the disease spreads to other parts of the body – which cuts short 1,000 UK women’s lives each month.

So get out your pink shirts, ties and tutus and ‘wear it pink’ on Wednesday 12 October.

Please make your donation here.
posts.excerpt: ‘Wear it pink’ on Wednesday 12 October and raise money for breast cancer.

posts.title: Student Wellbeing Service Workshops
posts.content:
A Survival Guide to Panic

Date: Tuesday 11 October

Time: 1.30pm–3pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This workshop is designed to take some of the fear out of panic attacks. By understanding what panic attacks are and why we have them, we can start to understand how to cope with them better.  Participants will learn the science of panic attacks, why it is they keep on happening and what can be done to help.  To enrol for this workshop it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception

 

From Stress to Success (four week course)

Dates: Wednesday 12, 19 and 26 October, 2 November

Time: 3.30pm-5.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This is a skills-based course designed to help students understand and manage the impact of stress more effectively. It will focs on work/life balance, time management, communication skills, assertiveness, negative thinking, problem solving and relaxation. The course uses techniques from cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), a well-proven educational psychological approach that emphasises the influence of thinking on our moods and behaviour. To enrol for this course it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception

 

Keep Calm and Carry On (four week course)

Dates: Tuesday 18 and 25 October, 1 and 8 November

Time: 3.30pm-5.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This course teaches ways to cope more effectively with anxiety. If we are anxious, we often end up organising our lives around our fears and this can be very restricting. If you find that you’re worrying all the time, perhaps about things that are a part of everyday life, or about things that aren’t even likely to happen, then this course is for you. Based on cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), a well-proven educational psychological approach, this course will teach participants to identify and manage the triggers and symptoms of anxiety, to gain insight and to practice skills to cope. To enrol for this course it is necessary to be registered with a Portsmouth GP.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception

 

Facing Feelings

Date: Tuesday 18 October

Time: 1.30pm–3.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This workshop draws on proven techniques to improve our ability to understand, accept and manage difficult feelings, and to increase the tolerance of distress. The focus is on gaining skills to increase self-awareness and to improve our relationships and self-esteem.

There will be no expectation to share personal information or experience.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception

 

Living Like You Mean It

Date: Tuesday 18 October

Time: 1.30pm–4.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This workshop explores ways to develop a richer, more meaningful life. If you find yourself ‘playing it safe’ more than you would wish and avoiding things that you might enjoy because they involve challenge or anxiety, then this workshop could help you to overcome those barriers and to live your life more fully. Drawing on evidence-based approaches, participants will learn how to take effective action despite uncertainties and difficulties and to become more engaged and present in their lives.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception

 

Mindfulness Techniques

Date: Wednesday 19 October

Time: 1.30pm–3.00pm

Venue: Nuffield Centre

This is a taster course for students who are interested in the concept of mindfulness and are new to mindfulness practice. Mindfulness is a simple training technique that encourages heightened awareness of the here and now and the development of a non-judgemental acceptance. It promotes ways of staying with what is, rather than thinking about what might have been or worrying about what could be. Regular mindful practice can lead to more informed decisions about how you lead your life and this course will enable you to discover if this approach can work for you.

For more information or to book a place on this workshop:

Email wellbeing-admin@port.ac.uk; phone 023 9284 3466; or call in to the Nuffield Reception
posts.excerpt: Five different workshops to improve your wellbeing.

posts.title: Football opportunities for females
posts.content:
The Department of Sport and Recreation is running a series of football opportunities for all female students, staff and community members throughout 10–16 October, including playing and coaching events:

  • Mon 10 Oct, 6.30pm–7.30pm, drop-in football session at Langstone Campus (open to all female students)
  • Tues 11 Oct, 4.00pm in Eldon W1.02, Football Coaching Introduction
  • Thurs 13 Oct, 5.30pm–7.00pm, girls aged 10–16yrs drop-in football session at Langstone Campus
  • Thurs 13 Oct, 6.00pm–7.00pm, drop-in football session at Langstone Campus (open to all females 16 yrs +)

No previous experience is necessary, so if you just want to try something new, come and give it a go! Sessions are relaxed, informal and we provide a social environment, so come and see what we’re all about!   For more information, please contact rachel.robilliard@port.ac.uk
posts.excerpt: Check out all the female football opportunities we have going on throughout Girls’ Football Week (10–16 October)
